passage.text: Oxidative removal of bisphenol A by permanganate: Kinetics, pathways and influences of co-existing chemicals
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

► KMnO4 was very effective and selective for BPA degradation. ► BPA oxidation by KMnO4 was significantly enhanced with increasing temperature. ► A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. ► The pathways of BPA oxidation by KMnO4 were proposed for the first time. Batch experiments were carried out to investigate the decomposition of bisphenol A (BPA) by permanganate. Permanganate (100 μM) was very effective for BPA degradation and over 99% BPA (5 μM) was eliminated in 15 min at pH 7.0. A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. The rate constants of permanganate reaction with BPA were strongly dependent on temperature and the activation energy was determined to be 67.8 kJ mol−1. Eleven degradation intermediates were observed by LC–MS/MS and the pathways of BPA degradation by permanganate were proposed. The intermediates generated in the processes of BPA oxidation by permanganate, ferrate, ozone, chlorine or hydroxyl radical indicated that benzoic ring was the reaction site at the early stage of BPA oxidation by various oxidants. The presence of humic acid (HA), HCO3-, Fe2+ and Fe3+ at their environmentally relevant concentrations enhanced BPA removal following the order: HA > HCO3- > Fe2+> Fe3+. BPA degradation in tap water, river water, and synthetic water at pH 7.0 was faster than that in deionized water, indicating that permanganate was selective for BPA oxidation. These results suggested that permanganate oxidation is an effective method for the purification of waters containing phenolic EDCs.
Tables
Figures

(a) Time course of BPA (5 μM) oxidation by permanganate (100 μM) at pH 7.0 and (b) linear relationship between measured pseudo-first-order rate constants (kobs, s−1) and permanganate concentrations at pH 7.0.
Arrhenius plot for the BPA degradation rate constants at 10, 15, 20, 25 and 30 °C. Reaction conditions: [BPA]0 = 5 μM, [Mn(VII)]0 = 100 μM.
Effect of pH on second-order rate constants of BPA oxidation by permanganate (this study), chlorine (data obtained from
Proposed BPA degradation pathways by permanganate (compounds in the ovals were detected in this study).

Effects of (a) [Fe2+] or [Fe3+]; (b) [HCO3-]; (c) [HA] on BPA oxidative degradation by permanganate and (d) BPA oxidation by permanganate in deionized water, tap water, river water and synthetic water. Reaction conditions: [BPA]0 = 5 μM, [Mn(VII)]0 = 10 μM.
Highlights

► KMnO4 was very effective and selective for BPA degradation. ► BPA oxidation by KMnO4 was significantly enhanced with increasing temperature. ► A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. ► The pathways of BPA oxidation by KMnO4 were proposed for the first time. Batch experiments were carried out to investigate the decomposition of bisphenol A (BPA) by permanganate. Permanganate (100 μM) was very effective for BPA degradation and over 99% BPA (5 μM) was eliminated in 15 min at pH 7.0. A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by aqueous permanganate was found over the pH range of 4.0–11.0. The rate constants of permanganate reaction with BPA were strongly dependent on temperature and the activation energy was determined to be 67.8 kJ mol−1. Eleven degradation intermediates were observed by LC–MS/MS and the pathways of BPA degradation by permanganate were proposed. The intermediates generated in the processes of BPA oxidation by permanganate, ferrate, ozone, chlorine or hydroxyl radical indicated that benzoic ring was the reaction site at the early stage of BPA oxidation by various oxidants. The presence of humic acid (HA), HCO3-, Fe2+ and Fe3+ at their environmentally relevant concentrations enhanced BPA removal following the order: HA > HCO3- > Fe2+> Fe3+. BPA degradation in tap water, river water, and synthetic water at pH 7.0 was faster than that in deionized water, indicating that permanganate was selective for BPA oxidation. These results suggested that permanganate oxidation is an effective method for the purification of waters containing phenolic EDCs.
keywords
['Permanganate', 'Endocrine disrupting chemicals', 'Oxidation products', 'Mineralization', 'Water treatment', '1']
Introduction

Endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) can mimic the biological activity of natural hormones, occupy (but not active) the hormone receptors, or interfere the transport and metabolic processes of natural hormones Several methods have been developed to remove BPA from water including activated carbon adsorption, electrochemical oxidation, ozonation, photocatalytic decomposition and biological procedures Permanganate has been widely used in potable water treatment for enhancing coagulation and removing micropollutants and in remediation of contaminated groundwater Therefore, the objectives of this study were to (1) determine the kinetics of BPA removal by permanganate in aqueous solution as functions of reactant concentration, pH and temperature; (2) detect the intermediates of reaction and propose reasonable BPA degradation pathways; (3) examine the influence of co-existing chemicals on this process to show the selectivity of permanganate oxidation. 2
Experimental section
Reagents and chemicals

BPA, KMnO4 and the scavenger Na2S2O3 were of analytical grade ( ). A commercial HA purchased from Jiangxi Reagent Co., Ltd., China, was used as a surrogate of humic substance and purified by repeated pH adjustment, precipitation, and centrifugation to remove ash, humin, and fulvic acid, completely following the procedure described by Kilduff and Weber ). 2.2
Batch experiments and analyses

All experiments on the kinetics of BPA oxidation by KMnO4 were conducted in brown glass bottles with stopples at pH 7.0 ± 0.1 and 20 ± 1 °C unless otherwise specified. The headspace of the glass bottles to aqueous phase ratio was 1:10 by volume. In a typical experiment, brown glass bottles containing 200 mL of BPA and 30 mM NaCl (as background electrolyte) were put in water bath for at least 30 min to ensure the temperature of the reactant was 20 °C. The experiments were initiated after addition of an aliquot of the permanganate stock solution into the reactor while stirring, and the reaction lasted 20 min. At fixed time intervals 10 mL of sample was rapidly transferred with a syringe to a small beaker containing 100 μL of Na2S2O3 (0.1 M) to terminate the reaction immediately, and filtrated with a membrane filter (pore size, 0.22 μm). The concentration of residual BPA was analyzed directly by HPLC. No buffer was used at pH 4.0–7.0 and borate buffer was used at pH 8.0–9.0. The pH values changed very little (<0.1) during the whole process and all pH values reported were initial pH. The residual trace amount of MnO2 after filtration and ionic strength (30 mM NaCl) had little effects on the BPA degradation (data not shown). It should be notified that the initial concentration of permanganate was controlled at 10 μM in order to keep consistent with the pilot application in the experiments to verify the influence of co-existing ions on BPA oxidation by permanganate. All experiments were run in duplicates or triplicates, and all points in the figures are the mean of the results and error bars represent standard deviation of the means. BPA concentration was quantified by HPLC on a Waters e2695 instrument with a Symmetry C18 column (2.1 mm × 150 mm, 3.5 μm) and UV–Visible detector (Waters 2489) set at 280 nm. The mobile phase, water/methanol (30/70, v/v), was run in an isocratic mode and the flow rate was 1 mL min−1. The intermediates were identified by LC–MS/MS ( ). BPA mineralization (DOC removal) was examined with a TOC-VCPH analyzer (Shimadzu). 3
Results and discussion
Reaction order and constants of permanganate with BPA

The reaction law of BPA with permanganate was investigated with a molar ratio of permanganate to BPA ⩾ 5:1 in a batch reactor. The loss of BPA followed pseudo-first-order kinetics within the time scales investigated, as illustrated in a. For a constant concentration of BPA (5 μM) at pH 7.0, the pseudo-first-order rate constant (kobs, s−1) increased linearly as increasing Mn(VII) concentration from 25 to 150 μM ( b), demonstrating a first-order dependence of the reaction on Mn(VII). Thus, the oxidation kinetics of BPA by Mn(VII) could be described by a second-order rate law: (1) -d[BPA]dt=kobs[BPA]=kapp[KMnO4][BPA] (2) lnkobs=lnkapp+ln[KMnO4] where kapp (M−1 s−1) was the second-order reaction rate constant. kapp at pH 7.0 and 20 °C was determined to be 28.53 M−1 s−1, slightly smaller than the kapp (35.8 M−1 s−1) at 23 °C reported by Jiang et al. The reaction rate of permanganate with BPA is of the same order as photo-catalytic degradation of BPA with kapp of 72 M−1 s−1 at pH 7.0 and 25 °C 3.2
Effect of temperature on BPA degradation

BPA oxidation by permanganate was strongly dependent on temperature since the kapp of BPA destruction by permanganate increased significantly from 16.32 to 1.03 × 102 M−1 s−1 within creasing temperatures from 10 °C to 30 °C, as shown in and . (3) lnkapp=lnA-EaRT According to the Arrhenius equation (Eq. ), plotting ln(kapp) vs. 1/T would yield a linear curve, as shown in , and the activation energy (Ea) was determined to be 67.8 kJ mol−1. This Ea value was very close to that of antibiotics (lincomycin, 68.4 kJ mol−1) oxidation by permanganate 3.3
Effect of pH on BPA degradation

demonstrates that the rate of BPA oxidation by permanganate is heavily dependent on pH. There was a slight increase in kapp as pH decreased from 5.0 to 4.0, which should be associated with acid catalysis under increased [H+] condition A comparison of the pH-dependent second-order rate constants of BPA oxidation by permanganate, chlorine and ozone was made in . At near neutral pH, permanganate exhibited comparable reactivity with chlorine but much lower reactivity than ozone. The interesting phenomenon that kapp reached their maximum at BPA’s first pKa (9.2) in all the three oxidative processes and then decreased, similar to the behavior of chlorophenols oxidation by permanganate 3.4
Pathways of BPA by permanganate oxidation

Although many studies have made efforts to explore the BPA oxidation pathways in various processes . All the intermediates eluted earlier than BPA, indicating that they were more polar than their parent compound . Relying on the intermediates specified in this study, Adamezyk and Paneth’s theoretical evaluation . In the early stage of the reaction, permanganate oxidized phenolic compounds through [3 + 2] addition across the O–Mn–O, followed by a hydride abstraction (rate-limiting step) from the substrate to permanganate oxo group The 4-isopropenylphenol (m/z 134) was the smallest molecular with benzoic ring detected in this study. Its concentration reached the maximum in less than 30 min, while ∼99% of BPA was degraded in the first 15 min and only 50% mineralization achieved (as DOC) in 3 h ( ). It implied that the precursors of 4-isopropenylphenol were susceptible to oxidization while its degradation products were resistant to permanganate oxidation. This phenomenon was similar to BPA mineralization by ozone, during which additional 4 h of ozonation only achieved about 16% additional DOC removal The initial degradation byproducts (m/z 244, 242, 276 and 152) of BPA verified in permanganate, ferrate, manganese dioxide, ozone and hydroxyl oxidation processes showed no change on the alkyl group, as listed in , indicating that the benzoic ring was the reaction site at early stage of BPA oxidation by various oxidants. The mono-hydroxylated BPA was the first product derived from BPA by adding the second –OH group on the ring in permanganate oxidation ( ). Many studies have reported that the phenolic moiety is the essential functional group responsible for the strong estrogenicity, while the quinone-like and aromatic ring-opening oxidation products hold much weaker estrogenic potency 3.5
Effect of co-existing materials on BPA degradation efficiency

Most studies on permanganate oxidation were carried out in distilled water and the effects of the background matrixes in the natural water were rarely taken into account and . The presence of Ca2+ of 0–1.5 mM, Mg2+ of 0–1.6 mM, SO42- of 0–0.1 mM and SiO32- of 0–2.0 mM had negligible influences on BPA removal. Increasing Fe3+ from 0 to 20 μM enhanced the BPA removal rate from 34.1% to 49.3%. However, further increasing in its concentration resulted in a drop in the removal of BPA. Fe2+ did not inhibit BPA removal by permanganate over the concentration range of 5–60 μM. The maximum BPA removal rate (45.5%) was achieved in the presence of 20 μM Fe2+. Bicarbonate improved BPA removal almost linearly from 34.1% to 49.9% with increasing its concentration from 0 to 10 mM. The stimulative capacity of these ions at their own environmentally relevant concentrations generally followed the order: HCO3->Fe2+>Fe3+>Ca2+≈Mg2+≈SO42-≈SiO32-·HCO3- exhibited the strongest promotion on BPA degradation by permanganate compared to other ions studied. The recent study has proved the HCO3- can participant the hydroxyl oxidation acting as CO3·- or HCO3· The influence of HA on BPA degradation by permanganate was illustrated in c. BPA removal was improved from 34.1% to 73.8% by increasing HA concentration from 0 to 7.5 mg C L−1 as DOC. As reported by Nanny and Maza To sum up, comparing our results to other techniques such as ozonation and advanced oxidation processes, the reaction rate of permanganate oxidation was lower. But none of the co-existing ions examined in our study displayed negative influence while Fe2+, Fe3+, HCO3- and HA could enhance permanganate oxidation. This may indicate that permanganate oxidation bored high selectivity for BPA in real water with various background matrixes. Therefore, BPA spiked in tap water, river water, and synthetic water was removed by permanganate at pH 7.0, as shown in d. Apparently, compared to the oxidation kinetics obtained in deionized water, BPA oxidation was accelerated in all of these three water matrices, consistent with the influence of co-existing ions on permanganate oxidation process. The latest research also showed that permanganate oxidation was more effective than chlorination and ozonation in treatment of surface water and wastewater effluent at pH 8.0 when the oxidant doses were relatively low 4
Conclusions

This study demonstrated that permanganate was a good alternative for the treatment of aqueous phenolic EDCs. BPA removal was highly pH and temperature dependent. A parabola-like shaped pH-rate profile for BPA oxidation by permanganate was found in the pH range of 4.0–11.0. The proposed reaction pathways of BPA degradation by permanganate were very similar to those of BPA destruction by ozonation. Benzoic ring was the reaction site at the early stage of BPA oxidation by permanganate, ferrate, ozone, chlorine and hydroxyl radical. The co-existing solutes in the natural water had no negative effects on the BPA degradation and the presence of HCO3-, Fe2+, Fe3+ and HA could enhance the BPA removal to different degrees. Although BPA can be effectively removed by many advanced oxidation processes in pure water, permanganate is stable, inexpensive, and more importantly, permanganate oxidation showed highly selectivity for BPA in real water. Therefore, permanganate oxidation is a promising process for BPA removal from natural water with various background solutes. Appendix A
